name: Volcanic Eruption
description: The ground trembles as a nearby volcano erupts, spewing ash and lava into the sky.

outcomes.description: You escape but suffer minor burns from falling ash.
You escape unharmed but are exhausted from the sprint.

choices.scientificContext: Volcanic eruptions were common throughout the Mesozoic Era, particularly during the Deccan Traps eruptions that contributed to the K-Pg extinction.

choices.text: Search for a cave or overhang

outcomes.description: You find shelter and rest safely while the eruption subsides.
Your survival in extreme heat has toughened you.
The cave you found offers poor protection from toxic gases.

choices.scientificContext: Animals during volcanic events would seek shelter from pyroclastic flows and toxic gases like sulfur dioxide.

scientificFacts: The Deccan Traps in India erupted around the same time as the K-Pg extinction event.
Volcanic winters caused by ash blocking sunlight could last for years.
Some dinosaurs may have survived initial eruptions only to starve as plant life died.

name: Flash Flood
description: Heavy monsoon rains have caused the river to overflow. Water rushes toward you!

outcomes.description: The floodwaters expose ancient fossils in the eroding bank.
You wait safely until the waters recede.

choices.scientificContext: Many dinosaur fossils were preserved precisely because of flood events that rapidly buried carcasses.

outcomes.description: You navigate the waters expertly and find treasures washed downstream.
The current is stronger than expected.

choices.scientificContext: Semi-aquatic dinosaurs like Spinosaurus would have thrived in flood conditions.

scientificFacts: Seasonal flooding was common in Mesozoic river systems.
Flash floods were a major cause of dinosaur mass mortality events.
The famous Ghost Ranch Coelophysis quarry may represent a flash flood burial.

name: Tar Pit
description: You come across a bubbling tar pit. Something struggles within - prey or trap?

outcomes.description: You observe bones preserved in the tar and learn about this natural trap.

choices.scientificContext: Tar pits like La Brea have preserved countless prehistoric animals, including mammals, birds, and insects.

outcomes.description: An easy meal awaits!
You get too close and become partially stuck yourself!

choices.scientificContext: Predators often became trapped when attempting to prey on stuck animals.

choices.text: Try to help the struggling creature

outcomes.description: Your efforts coat you in tar, providing unexpected protection.
The creature escapes and may remember your kindness.
Despite your strength, the tar nearly claims you too.

choices.scientificContext: The ratio of predators to prey in tar pit fossils is unnaturally high, showing predators frequently became victims.

scientificFacts: Tar pits formed from crude oil seeping to the surface.
Animals stuck in tar attracted predators who also became trapped.
La Brea Tar Pits preserved over 3.5 million specimens.

name: Meteor Shower
description: The night sky lights up with streaking meteors. Some seem dangerously close...

choices.text: Watch in awe from a safe distance

outcomes.description: You learn about the asteroid that ended the age of dinosaurs.
Your awareness of cosmic threats is heightened.

choices.scientificContext: The Chicxulub impactor that ended the dinosaurs was about 10-15 km in diameter.

outcomes.description: You find a rare space rock still warm from its journey!
A nearby impact injures you with debris.
Exposure to extraterrestrial minerals grants strange properties.

choices.scientificContext: Iridium from the K-Pg boundary layer is evidence of the asteroid impact.

scientificFacts: The Chicxulub asteroid released energy equivalent to 100 trillion tons of TNT.
The impact winter that followed blocked sunlight for years.
About 75% of all species went extinct in the aftermath.

name: Severe Drought
description: The water hole is almost dry. Several dinosaurs gather at the shrinking pool, tension in the air.

outcomes.description: You drink your fill after the larger dinosaurs leave.
The water runs out before you can drink enough.

choices.scientificContext: Drought conditions forced even competing species to share water sources.

outcomes.description: A desperate herbivore challenges you!
Your display of strength grants you first access.
Others remember your dominance at this water hole.

choices.scientificContext: Competition for water during droughts led to unusual predator-prey interactions.

outcomes.description: Your powerful legs unearth a fresh spring!
The digging exhausts you without finding water.

choices.scientificContext: Modern elephants dig for water during droughts - dinosaurs may have done the same.

scientificFacts: Bone beds often represent drought-related mass mortality events.
Seasonal droughts were common in the Mesozoic interior.
Dinosaurs may have migrated to follow water sources.

name: Great Migration
description: A massive herd of hadrosaurs thunders across the landscape in their annual migration.

outcomes.description: You travel safely among the herd and learn their routes.
A territorial bull charges you for getting too close.

choices.scientificContext: Evidence suggests some dinosaurs migrated seasonally, similar to modern wildebeest.

outcomes.description: An easy meal from an exhausted juvenile.
A protective adult notices your approach!

choices.scientificContext: Predators commonly targeted young, old, or sick individuals during migrations.

outcomes.description: You rest and observe from a safe distance.

choices.scientificContext: A stampeding hadrosaur herd would have been extremely dangerous to anything in their path.

scientificFacts: Hadrosaur trackways suggest herds of thousands of individuals.
Migration routes may have spanned hundreds of kilometers.
Nesting grounds were often distant from feeding areas.

name: Nesting Ground Discovery
description: You stumble upon a dinosaur nesting ground with eggs partially buried in vegetation.

outcomes.description: A protein-rich meal restores your strength.
The parent returns and attacks!

choices.scientificContext: Many dinosaurs were opportunistic egg-eaters, including Oviraptor (though its name is a misnomer).

outcomes.description: You learn about dinosaur reproductive behavior.
Understanding nesting helps you find more resources.

choices.scientificContext: Maiasaura fossils showed evidence of parental care, changing our view of dinosaur behavior.

choices.text: Guard the nest from other predators

outcomes.description: The returning parent sees you as an ally.
You must fight off an egg-stealing predator.
Your vigilance is rewarded when the grateful parent shares food.

choices.scientificContext: Some dinosaurs may have formed symbiotic relationships for nest protection.

scientificFacts: Dinosaur eggs were typically laid in clutches of 10-40 eggs.
Some nests show evidence of multiple layers from returning parents.
Eggshell fragments help identify dinosaur species at fossil sites.

name: Prehistoric Insect Swarm
description: A massive swarm of prehistoric insects descends upon the area.

outcomes.description: The insects bite and sting but eventually move on.
Some bites become infected.

choices.scientificContext: Mesozoic insects were vectors for diseases and parasites affecting dinosaurs.

outcomes.description: The mud coating protects you from bites.
You learn the value of mud as natural protection.

choices.scientificContext: Modern animals like elephants and rhinos use mud baths for insect protection.

outcomes.description: You catch and eat hundreds of nutritious insects.
You develop a taste for this easy prey.

choices.scientificContext: Many small dinosaurs and pterosaurs were insectivores.

scientificFacts: Mesozoic insects included giant dragonflies with 70cm wingspans.
Mosquito-like insects may have plagued dinosaurs.
Insect fossils in amber preserve amazing details of prehistoric life.

name: Amber Deposit
description: Golden resin oozes from ancient conifers, trapping small creatures forever.

outcomes.description: You find several beautiful amber pieces with preserved insects.
Fresh resin gets stuck to you.

choices.scientificContext: Amber has preserved prehistoric life in incredible detail, including feathers and blood cells.

outcomes.description: You learn about this unique form of fossilization.
Your observation skills improve.

choices.scientificContext: Amber from Myanmar has preserved feathered dinosaur tails and ancient birds.

scientificFacts: Amber is fossilized tree resin, not sap.
The oldest amber with inclusions is about 230 million years old.
Amber can preserve soft tissues, DNA is too degraded to extract.

name: Apex Predator Territory
description: Fresh kills and territorial markings indicate you've entered a large predator's territory.

outcomes.description: You pass through undetected.
The territory owner finds you!

choices.scientificContext: Predators like T. rex likely had territories spanning many square kilometers.

outcomes.description: You find fresh meat and eat quickly.
The predator returns to its kill!

choices.scientificContext: Scavenging was common behavior - even T. rex likely scavenged when possible.

outcomes.description: The apex predator accepts your challenge!
The predator retreats, recognizing your dominance.

choices.scientificContext: Territorial disputes likely resulted in many dinosaur injuries seen in fossils.

scientificFacts: Bite marks on dinosaur bones show intraspecific combat was common.
Apex predators needed large territories to find enough food.
Territorial behavior is seen in most modern large predators.

name: Ancient Forest
description: Towering conifers and ginkgoes create a primeval forest teeming with life.

outcomes.description: You find nutritious ferns and seeds.
Some plants prove toxic!

choices.scientificContext: Mesozoic forests were dominated by conifers, ferns, and ginkgoes - flowering plants were just emerging.

choices.text: Hunt small creatures in the undergrowth

outcomes.description: You catch small mammals and lizards.
You learn about the small mammals that lived alongside dinosaurs.

choices.scientificContext: Small mammals thrived in the shadow of dinosaurs, mostly nocturnal to avoid predators.

outcomes.description: You find bird nests and unique vantage points.
A branch breaks under your weight.

choices.scientificContext: Arboreal dinosaurs like Microraptor hunted in forest canopies.

scientificFacts: Flowering plants only became dominant late in the Cretaceous.
Ginkgoes are living fossils, largely unchanged since the Mesozoic.
Forest fires were common and helped shape dinosaur ecosystems.

name: Mysterious Illness
description: Dead and dying dinosaurs litter the landscape. A disease sweeps through the population.

choices.text: Avoid all contact with the sick

outcomes.description: Your caution keeps you safe.
Despite your efforts, you contract the illness.

choices.scientificContext: Dinosaur bones show evidence of infections, tumors, and other diseases.

outcomes.description: Easy meals from the victims.
Eating diseased flesh was unwise.

choices.scientificContext: Disease transmission through scavenging affected predator populations.

outcomes.description: You find plants that boost your immunity.
The plants have general healing properties.

choices.scientificContext: Modern animals practice self-medication - dinosaurs may have done the same.

scientificFacts: Dinosaur fossils show evidence of bone infections and cancers.
Parasites including intestinal worms have been found in dinosaur coprolites.
Disease may have contributed to some local extinctions before the K-Pg event.

name: Petrified Forest
description: An ancient forest turned to stone. Massive petrified logs stretch across the landscape.

outcomes.description: You learn how wood becomes stone over millions of years.
Your understanding of deep time expands.

choices.scientificContext: Petrified forests form when volcanic ash buries trees and silica replaces organic material.

choices.text: Search between the logs for fossils

outcomes.description: The preserved forest contains many trapped creatures.
Sharp petrified wood cuts you.

choices.scientificContext: Petrified forests often preserve entire ecosystems including animals.

scientificFacts: The Petrified Forest in Arizona is about 225 million years old.
Petrified wood can contain agate, jasper, and other minerals.
Some petrified logs are over 200 feet long.

name: Rival Pack
description: You encounter a pack of your own species. Will they accept you or see you as a rival?

outcomes.description: The pack accepts you as a subordinate member.
You receive a warning bite but are tolerated.

choices.scientificContext: Pack dynamics in dromaeosaurids likely involved complex social hierarchies.

outcomes.description: The alpha accepts your challenge!
Your display of strength makes the alpha back down.

choices.scientificContext: Leadership challenges in predator packs often involved ritualized combat.

outcomes.description: Together you take down impressive prey!
The successful hunt bonds you to this pack.

choices.scientificContext: Fossil evidence suggests dromaeosaurids hunted in coordinated groups.

scientificFacts: Multiple Deinonychus fossils found with Tenontosaurus suggest pack hunting.
Pack size may have varied seasonally with prey availability.
Social hunting allowed taking prey much larger than individual hunters.
